meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 皮膚 is "skin?" Well the <kanji>science</kanji> of skin is <vocabulary>dermatology</vocabulary>!
Remember how you learned that 皮膚 is "skin?" Well when your skin is <kanji>sick</kanji>, you have a <vocabulary>skin disease</vocabulary>. You should probably go to a dermatologist right away.
The <kanji>origin</kanji> of your <kanji>collar</kanji> is your <vocabulary>collar</vocabulary>! And the <vocabulary>nape of the neck</vocabulary> because that's where collars go.
Remember how you learned that 巻く means "to roll?" Well the thing you roll up around your <kanji>collar</kanji> is a <vocabulary>scarf</vocabulary>!

A miner works with such <kanji>sincerity</kanji> that her arms and legs start turning <kanji>rust colored</kanji> from <vocabulary>working earnestly</vocabulary>. All the clay and rocks she's putting her <vocabulary>effort</vocabulary> into digging are turning her the same color. That color is how you know someone works with serious <vocabulary>diligence</vocabulary>.

If you don't want your <kanji>thought</kanji>s to turn <kanji>rust colored</kanji>, you need to be <vocabulary>diligent</vocabulary> and studying, learning, and experiencing new things. Without diligence your brain and all your thoughts will get old, and stale, turning a rusty, gross color.
If there is only <kanji>semi</kanji> <kanji>criticism</kanji> on a law <vocabulary>ratification</vocabulary> is still possible. It's only if everyone criticizes it that it won't be ratified.

If you <kanji>surpass</kanji> your <kanji>surplus</kanji> then you have lots of <vocabulary>excess</vocabulary> stuff.

過剰 is a relatively formal word that refers to something being <vocabulary>excessive</vocabulary>. It can also often mean <vocabulary>over</vocabulary> — like overconsumption, overreaction, or overproduction — in various contexts related to behaviors, emotions, or physical quantities.
If you have a <kanji>surplus</kanji> <kanji>surplus</kanji> it's a little <vocabulary>redundant</vocabulary> and you end up having a <vocabulary>surplus</vocabulary> of surpluses!
<kanji>Surplus</kanji> of <kanji>surplus</kanji> <kanji>money</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>surplus</vocabulary>. There's just too much money everywhere!

You've learned that 召す can mean "to take" when a social higher-up takes a meal or a drink. Now you're adding 上がる (to go up), so you've got the added image of the food or drink rising up to their mouth. In other words, this is a respectful way of saying <vocabulary>to eat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to drink</vocabulary>.

What <kanji>indicate</kanji>s that you've been <kanji>enlighten</kanji>ed enough to reach enlightenment? A <vocabulary>revelation</vocabulary>! That's the only way you can know you've been enlightened enough.
When you are <kanji>enlighten</kanji>ed enough you'll need to make your <kanji>departure</kanji> from this world into <vocabulary>enlightenment</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Enlighten</kanji> the <kanji>darkness</kanji> of people's minds with <vocabulary>instruction</vocabulary> and they'll reach <vocabulary>enlightenment</vocabulary> like you did!
<kanji>Soil</kanji> <kanji>soil</kanji> is still <kanji>soil</kanji>.

What's the city of <kanji>flat</kanji> <kanji>soil</kanji>? <vocabulary>Pyongyang</vocabulary> in North Korea. Which is pretty misleading, it's got more than a bunch of flat dirt, but back in the old days before the illustrious Kim Jong line built it up, that's all that was there.
It doesn't matter how <kanji>big</kanji> your <kanji>tolerance</kanji> is because it's still <vocabulary>tolerance</vocabulary>.

All <kanji>forms</kanji> of <kanji>tolerance</kanji> are still <vocabulary>tolerance</vocabulary>. Usually people like this are really <vocabulary>open minded</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>generous</vocabulary> too.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>tolerance</kanji>, so the verb version is what happens when you're a really tolerant person. You're able <vocabulary>to relax</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to feel at home</vocabulary> because nothing really gets to you.
The <kanji>commander</kanji>'s <kanji>origin</kanji> was as the <vocabulary>general of the army</vocabulary>. He stepped down, but that's where he started. Maybe he's working the system backwards...
The <kanji>commander</kanji> of the <kanji>whole</kanji> army is just called " the <vocabulary>commander</vocabulary>." No one knows his real name and everyone is too afraid to ask.

The <kanji>commander</kanji> that <kanji>unite</kanji>s and <kanji>rule</kanji>s the world is one with <vocabulary>supreme command</vocabulary>. He's better than all the other commanders who couldn't bring everyone together and now he rules over everyone.
If you <kanji>go</kanji> <kanji>gently</kanji> you're actually <vocabulary>going slowly</vocabulary>. You can't be gentle if you don't move slowly.

If you do it <kanji>gently</kanji> <kanji>gently</kanji> then you're only doing it <vocabulary>gradually</vocabulary>. You have to go <vocabulary>slowly</vocabulary> if you want to be as gentle as possible.

A <kanji>disaster</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>tragedy</vocabulary>. Look away!

惨事 is a formal word for a tragic or <vocabulary>gruesome event</vocabulary> — the kind that's so distressing it makes you want to avert your eyes. It emphasizes the horror and emotional pain of the event.
A <kanji>sad</kanji> <kanji>disaster</kanji> is one that's especially <vocabulary>disastrous</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>tragic</vocabulary>. It's the worst kind you can imagine.

If you face a lot of <kanji>disaster</kanji>s in your life you're going to be really <vocabulary>miserable</vocabulary>. It's a shame, but it's hard to be anything but <vocabulary>wretched</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>pathetic</vocabulary> when your life is full of disastrous stuff.

惨め describes someone or something as miserable, usually emphasizing sadness or failure in emotional or social situations. When you describe yourself as 惨め, it expresses a strong sense of helplessness and humiliation.
<kanji>Failure</kanji> that causes <kanji>disaster</kanji> is a <vocabulary>crushing failure</vocabulary> and you were <vocabulary>utterly beaten</vocabulary> by your opponent.

<kanji>Disastrous</kanji> <kanji>condition</kanji>s in the weather lead to you seeing a <vocabulary>disastrous scene</vocabulary>. Just don't look outside and you won't see the horrible stuff out your window right now.
<kanji>Expose</kanji> what you want to <kanji>expose</kanji> by making an <vocabulary>announcement</vocabulary>. Then <vocabulary>show</vocabulary> the world!

You already learned the word 挟む is for putting something between two things. 挟まる is the intransitive version — it's used to describe when something gets caught between two things with no direct object. So it means <vocabulary>to get between</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be caught in</vocabulary>.

You use 挟まる for situations like your jacket getting caught in a car door, food getting stuck between your teeth, or a memo being tucked between pages.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>install</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to install</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fix</vocabulary>.

When something has already been <kanji>board</kanji>ed and <kanji>put on</kanji>to something, it comes <vocabulary>built in</vocabulary>.

搭載 refers to something built into or onto another object, which generally is a vehicle or a machine.

When you <kanji>board</kanji> a plane or a car to take a <kanji>ride</kanji> it's called <vocabulary>boarding</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>embarkation</vocabulary>. You have to get on the right way or you can't ride.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>wither</kanji>ed <kanji>tree</kanji> is a <vocabulary>dead tree</vocabulary> and it's got really <vocabulary>dry wood</vocabulary>. Perfect for a campfire!

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Allow A Plant To Wither
To Let A Plant Dry Up

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned 枯れる (to wither), but this is when you're the one making a plant wither, so it means <vocabulary>to let wither</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to kill a plant</vocabulary>.

枯らす literally means <vocabulary>to let something dry up</vocabulary>, usually by neglect or lack of water (though too much water can also 枯らす plants). It's often used when someone accidentally lets plants die, but it can also describe intentionally killing plants with a herbicide. You'll also see it used figuratively, like 声を枯らす (to lose one's voice).

You already learned the word 沸く which means "to boil" or "to grow hot" but this is when you are the one heating the water. It still means <vocabulary>to boil</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to heat</vocabulary>. But remember that you're the one who is doing the heating.

The <kanji>inflation</kanji> of <kanji>boil</kanji>ing water means that bubbles are being inflated in there and bubbling to the top. This is called <vocabulary>boiling</vocabulary>, or if it's happening in a person it's called <vocabulary>seething</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>purify</kanji> your <kanji>self</kanji> you are performing <vocabulary>self purification</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Purify</kanji> water to <kanji>change</kanji> it from being dirty. This is called <vocabulary>purification</vocabulary>. It's important to purify water before you drink it.
Land where all the people have been <kanji>cleanse</kanji>d and <kanji>purified</kanji> is the <vocabulary>Pure Land</vocabulary> of Buddhism.
If you have <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>cleanse</kanji>d yourself you're going to be covered in <vocabulary>uncleanliness</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dirtiness</vocabulary>. Eww.
When you <kanji>cleanse</kanji> <kanji>water</kanji> it becomes <vocabulary>clean water</vocabulary> that you can drink.
<kanji>Pure</kanji> <kanji>cleanse</kanji>d things are <vocabulary>pure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>clean</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>wash</kanji> something to <kanji>cleanse</kanji> it by doing the <vocabulary>washing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>cleaning</vocabulary>. You have to do the washing if you really want to get all the dirt out and make your things clean.
This is a combination of the word 渦 meaning "whirlpool" and 巻く meaning "to roll." A rolling whirlpool is still a <vocabulary>whirlpool</vocabulary>, just a really violent one.

A <kanji>mysterious</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is really really good at what they do. So good that they aren't exactly sure what is it they do, but you know they're definitely an <vocabulary>expert</vocabulary> at whatever it is.

玄人 is a relatively formal word that refers to a highly skilled <vocabulary>professional</vocabulary> in a specific field, as opposed to 素人 (amateur). In casual conversation, words like プロ (professional) are more common.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

In the <kanji>west</kanji>, <kanji>melons</kanji> are round and striped and green, and… Wait a second. That's a <vocabulary>watermelon</vocabulary>! I guess watermelons come from the western part of Japan?
Your <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>draft</kanji> is called a <vocabulary>manuscript</vocabulary>.
You end up writing your rough <kanji>draft</kanji> on some <kanji>grass</kanji> leaves because you forgot your <vocabulary>notes</vocabulary>. This grass will serve as your notes now.
<kanji>Throw</kanji> your <kanji>draft</kanji> at people to <vocabulary>post</vocabulary> it on their Facebook wall! Wait, that's not how it works? Hush, yes it does, just throw it harder.

稿料 is short for 原稿料, which is a combination of 原稿 (manuscript) and <kanji>fee</kanji>. Unsurprisingly, that makes this a <vocabulary>manuscript fee</vocabulary>. It's the <vocabulary>payment for writing</vocabulary> that an author gets for turning in their copy!
<kanji>Latitude</kanji> <kanji>degree</kanji>s are still known as <vocabulary>latitude</vocabulary>.
<kanji>South</kanji> <kanji>latitude</kanji> is <vocabulary>south latitude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>southern latitude</vocabulary>.
<kanji>North</kanji> <kanji>latitude</kanji> is <vocabulary>north latitude</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>northern latitude</vocabulary>.

If you are trying to <kanji>manage</kanji> <kanji>latitude</kanji>s you're really trying to manage the <vocabulary>details</vocabulary> of something. Managing latitudes is just a fancy way of saying it.
A <kanji>latitude</kanji> <kanji>line</kanji> can also be called a <vocabulary>parallel</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Fiber</kanji>s that have been <kanji>change</kanji>d from other materials are <vocabulary>synthetic fibers</vocabulary>. They aren't natural because they were something else once. Like plastic, or kittens.

Note that this is an abbreviation of the specialist term 化学繊維, and it mostly comes up in industrial contexts.
The <kanji>fiber</kanji> you use to <kanji>maintain</kanji> your own health is the <vocabulary>fiber</vocabulary> you eat!

<kanji>Fiber</kanji>s you <kanji>join</kanji> together to make more, stronger fibers, they turn into <vocabulary>synthetic fiber</vocabulary>s.

Note that this is an abbreviation of the specialist term 合成繊維, and it mostly comes up in industrial contexts.
<kanji>Slender</kanji> and <kanji>thin</kanji> things are very <vocabulary>delicate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>dainty</vocabulary>. They're easily broken, so you have to be careful.
If you want to show your <kanji>agreement</kanji> with someone you need <vocabulary>to nod</vocabulary> at them so they know.
The <kanji>child</kanji> of a <kanji>cell</kanji> is a <vocabulary>spore</vocabulary>. They're just as tiny and they're floating all around you right now.
<kanji>Thin</kanji> <kanji>cell</kanji>s are what make up our bodies. They're still <vocabulary>cells</vocabulary> but they can also be called <vocabulary>biological cells</vocabulary>.
People who have the <kanji>same</kanji> <kanji>cell</kanji>s as you are your <vocabulary>brethren</vocabulary>, they're your <vocabulary>brothers</vocabulary>!

When <kanji>barbarian</kanji>s <kanji>sit</kanji> they only <vocabulary>sit cross legged</vocabulary>. Sitting on your feet hurts and they don't care how they look, so they're going to be comfortable and cross their legs.

<kanji>Barbarian</kanji>s have <kanji>melon</kanji>s too, but they're long and funny looking. Wait, those aren't melons, they're <vocabulary>cucumber</vocabulary>s! Barbarians must have mixed them up.
The <kanji>fat</kanji> on an animal's <kanji>body</kanji> is called <vocabulary>fatty meat</vocabulary>. Some people really like to eat it and others really like to hate it.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that you won't actually see this used as a standalone word very often, except in the phrase 舗を構える (to open a shop), but even that is fairly rare!
A <kanji>shop</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>shop</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>pave</kanji> and <kanji>attire</kanji> something, you’ll end up with a <vocabulary>pavement</vocabulary>. Imagine the asphalt used in the paving of a street as its attire and this’ll make sense!
The <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>shop</kanji> is the <vocabulary>main shop</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>head office</vocabulary>.
What do a <kanji>warship</kanji> and a <kanji>rowboat</kanji> have in common? In wartime they're both considered <vocabulary>military vessel</vocabulary>s.
To <kanji>compete</kanji> in a <kanji>rowboat</kanji> is to take part in a <vocabulary>boat race</vocabulary>, also known as a <vocabulary>regatta</vocabulary>. Who are you gonna bet on?
A <kanji>seedling</kanji> <kanji>tree</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>seedling</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>bed</kanji> just for <kanji>seedling</kanji>s is called a <vocabulary>nursery</vocabulary>. It's where all the little seedling grow before they're sold or replanted outside.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The region of <kanji>darkness</kanji> in days of <kanji>old</kanji> referred to <vocabulary>Mongolia</vocabulary>. At least in China, where this word comes from. Imagine all those ancient Mongol tribes at the dark, unknown edges of China. Everything beyond the borders was shrouded in (figurative) darkness, I guess. No wonder they picked these kanji back then.
<kanji>Lotus</kanji> <kanji>root</kanji> is <vocabulary>lotus root</vocabulary>.

To <kanji>oppress</kanji> people and then <kanji>kill</kanji> them is an <vocabulary>atrocity</vocabulary>. It's also called a <vocabulary>massive killing</vocabulary> because that's what you're actually doing. And you're awful, why would you ever do that?

If you can't <kanji>wait</kanji> to <kanji>oppress</kanji> people when you grow up, you're the kind of person who's prone to inflicting <vocabulary>abuse</vocabulary> on other people. You should try to correct that right away.

The <kanji>remainder</kanji> of <kanji>oppress</kanji>ion is <vocabulary>cruelty</vocabulary>. Even when you're done oppressing people the <vocabulary>brutality</vocabulary> you caused will linger in their minds and hearts.
<kanji>Violence</kanji> and <kanji>oppress</kanji>ion are all signs of <vocabulary>tyranny</vocabulary> and that someone is being really <vocabulary>cruel</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>oppress</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to oppress</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to persecute</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>admonish</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to admonish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to warn</vocabulary>.

Who <kanji>admonish</kanji>es and <kanji>teach</kanji>es you? A <vocabulary>Teacher</vocabulary>. Probably not the nicest one though...

This word is more formal and specific than 先生 or 教師. It refers to licensed teachers who have permanent positions in schools, not temporary ones like supply teachers.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>brocade</kanji> <kanji>carp</kanji> is a fancy way of saying it's a carp that has a lot of pretty colors on it. It's a <vocabulary>colored carp</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>colored koi</vocabulary>.
If you have <kanji>all</kanji> the <kanji>time</kanji> in the world you can do whatever you want <vocabulary>at any time</vocabulary>.
<kanji>All</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji>s are <vocabulary>everywhere</vocabulary>.
<kanji>All</kanji> that comes out of a <kanji>writing brush</kanji> is <vocabulary>essay</vocabulary>s. You can't paint or doodle, you have to write with it.

If you manage to make <kanji>all</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>s of something work together you worked <vocabulary>very</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>extremely</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>considerably</vocabulary> hard to do it. Doing all of anything is hard so lots of work had to happen.
Even if you <kanji>follow</kanji> <kanji>all</kanji> the people you've ever met, you're still <vocabulary>follow</vocabulary>ing them. Once a follower, always a follower.

The kanji means <kanji>summit</kanji> and this word means <vocabulary>summit</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>top</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>crown</vocabulary>, most often in reference to mountains.

<kanji>Humbly</kanji> <kanji>receive</kanji> something and you'll be <vocabulary>humbly receiving</vocabulary> it. Or <vocabulary>humbly eating</vocabulary> it if they gave you food and not a puppy or something inedible. It can also mean <vocabulary>humbly having</vocabulary>. The theme here is humility!

This is usually formal when written in kanji and used together with a verb like する. It can also be used alone to make very casual requests. In casual requests, it's still written in kanji in novels and other creative writing, but is generally written in hiragana anywhere else.
<kanji>Tall</kanji> <kanji>inflation</kanji> of prices means that there was a <vocabulary>sudden price jump</vocabulary> and it's waaaay more expensive than it used to be.
<kanji>Violent</kanji> <kanji>inflation</kanji> causes a <vocabulary>sudden rise</vocabulary> in prices. It sucks.

<kanji>Sudden</kanji> <kanji>inflation</kanji> results in a <vocabulary>sudden rise</vocabulary> of prices, aka a sharp rise in prices.

急騰 is commonly used to refer to abrupt and unexpected rises in price or value, such as a <vocabulary>surge</vocabulary> in stock prices.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

A <kanji>scarlet</kanji> colored <kanji>carp</kanji> is called a <vocabulary>red carp</vocabulary> and sometimes a <vocabulary>golden carp</vocabulary> because sometimes people don't understand colors.
In <kanji>reality</kanji>, <kanji>carp</kanji> are usually <vocabulary>black carp</vocabulary>. The colored ones aren't as common, people just wish they were.

If you only <kanji>comprehend</kanji> <kanji>one</kanji> <kanji>guy</kanji>, make that guy <vocabulary>Ryoichiro</vocabulary>.

The name 諒一郎 isn't very common, but it's worth learning because the kanji 諒 is used in lots of names, and both 諒 and 一郎 are names in their own right. So by learning this name, you should be able to read a whole lot of other names, too.

<kanji>Jasmine</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is one way to write the girl's name <vocabulary>Riko</vocabulary>. Imagine fashioning a child out of jasmine, and calling her Riko. Examples of people named Riko include pop star and singer Fukumoto Riko (福本 莉子) and idol and actress Nakayama Riko (中山 莉子).

A <kanji>speed</kanji> <kanji>horse</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fast horse</vocabulary>, and a <vocabulary>fine horse</vocabulary>. This word isn't very common, but it does come up in horse racing contexts, and creative writing.

The kanji and the vocabulary are exactly the same, so this means <vocabulary>royal consort</vocabulary>. Depending on who she's married to, she could be a <vocabulary>queen</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>princess</vocabulary>, or even an <vocabulary>empress</vocabulary>. 

妃 can overlap in meaning with 后, but 后 is reserved for the highest-ranking consort, like an empress or queen, while 妃 is a more general word which includes lower-ranking consorts and the wives of other royal family members. In modern Japanese, the kana version きさき often appears in fairytale-style stories with kings and queens. But it's good to know both kanji, especially if you're reading anything historical.
